skills.substandard_description: Determine the literal meaning of words as they are used in a text.
Decode regularly spelled two-syllable words with long vowels.
Use adjectives.

Apply grade 6 Reading standards to literature (e.g., “Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres [e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories] in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics”).
Use punctuation to separate items in a series.
Explain the function of prepositions in general.

Write opinion pieces in which they introduce the topic or book they are writing about, state an opinion, supply reasons that support the opinion, use linking words (e.g., because, and, also) to connect opinion and reasons, and provide a concluding statement or section.
Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.
Conduct short research projects to answer a question, drawing on several sources and refocusing the inquiry when appropriate.
Distinguish long and short vowels when reading regularly spelled one-syllable words.
Follow rules for collegial discussions, set specific goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.

Apply grade 6 Reading standards to literature (e.g., “Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres [e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories] in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics”).

Apply grade 8 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., “Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced”).
Use context as a clue to the meaning of a phrase.
Use knowledge of the meaning of individual words to predict the meaning of compound words (e.g., birdhouse, lighthouse, housefly; bookshelf, notebook, bookmark).
Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Explain how a series of scenes fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular drama.
Produce, expand, and rearrange complete simple and compound sentences (e.g., The boy watched the movie; The little boy watched the movie; The action movie was watched by the little boy).
Choose between adjectives and adverbs depending on what is to be modified.
Identify real-life connections between words and their use (e.g., describe foods that are spicy or juicy).
Create audio recordings of stories or poems; add drawings or other visual displays to stories or recounts of experiences when appropriate to clarify ideas, thoughts, and feelings.
With guidance and support from adults, use a variety of digital tools to produce and publish writing, including in collaboration with peers.

Apply grade 5 Reading standards to informational texts (e.g., “Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point[s]”).
Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Use adverbs.
Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a phrase by using context clues, analyzing meaningful word parts, and consulting general and specialized reference materials, as appropriate.
Acknowledge differences in the points of view of characters.
Establish and maintain a formal style.
Analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning.
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from the argument presented.
Use context as a clue to the meaning of a phrase.
Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Produce complete sentences when appropriate to task and situation in order to provide requested detail or clarification. (See grade 2 Language standards 1 and 3 for specific expectations.)
Summarize the points a speaker makes and explain how each claim is supported by reasons and evidence.
Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Use a comma to separate an introductory element from the rest of the sentence.
Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and point of view and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.
Form and use frequently occurring irregular plural nouns (e.g., feet, children, teeth, mice, fish).
Spell correctly.
By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of grades 6–8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
Describe how reasons support specific points the author makes in a text.
Use words, phrases, and clauses to clarify the relationships among claim(s) and reasons.
Explain how a series of scenes fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular drama.

Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, including those that signal contrast, addition, and other logical relationships (e.g., however, although, nevertheless, similarly, moreover, in addition).
Use a comma to separate an introductory element from the rest of the sentence.
Identify the main purpose of a text, including what the author wants to answer, explain, or describe.
Ask and answer questions about what a speaker says in order to clarify comprehension, gather additional information, or deepen understanding of a topic or issue.
Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Use the relationship between particular words to better understand each of the words.
Distinguish long and short vowels when reading regularly spelled one-syllable words.
Identify real-life connections between words and their use (e.g., describe foods that are spicy or juicy).
Draw on information from multiple print or digital sources, demonstrating the ability to locate an answer to a question quickly or to solve a problem efficiently.
Distinguish shades of meaning among closely related verbs.
Read grade-level prose and poetry orally with accuracy, appropriate rate, and expression on successive readings.
Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.
Use accurately grade-appropriate general academic words and phrases.
Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Recognize inappropriate shifts in verb tense.

Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Expand complete compound sentences.

Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience. (Grade-specific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–3 above.)
Provide logically ordered reasons that are supported by facts and details.
Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.
Identify words with inconsistent but common spelling-sound correspondences.
Draw on information from multiple print or digital sources, demonstrating the ability to locate an answer to a question quickly or to solve a problem efficiently.
Determine the meaning of the new word formed when a known prefix is added to a known word (e.g., happy/unhappy, tell/retell).
Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin roots as clues to the meaning of a word.
Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.
Acknowledge new information expressed by others, and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views in light of the evidence presented.
Describe how a particular story’s plot unfolds in a series of episodes as the plot moves toward a resolution.

By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 6–8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and present the relationships between information and ideas efficiently as well as to interact and collaborate with others.
Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.
Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.

Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Describe how the beginning of a story introduces the story.

Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.
Compare formal and informal uses of English.
Rearrange complete compound sentences.
Analyze how a particular section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.

Write narratives in which they recount a well-elaborated event or short sequence of events, include details to describe actions, thoughts, and feelings, use temporal words to signal event order, and provide a sense of closure.
Interpret figures of speech (e.g. verbal irony, puns) in context.
Use a comma to indicate direct address.
Determine the meaning of the new word formed when a known prefix is added to a known word.

Introduce a topic clearly, previewing what is to follow; organize ideas, concepts, and information into broader categories; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.
With guidance and support from adults, use a variety of digital tools to produce and publish writing, including in collaboration with peers.
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.

Use words and phrases acquired through conversations, reading and being read to, and responding to texts, including using adjectives and adverbs to describe (e.g., When other kids are happy that makes me happy).
Include multimedia components (e.g., graphics, sound) and visual displays in presentations when appropriate to enhance the development of main ideas or themes.
Describe how a particular drama’s characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Delineate a speaker’s argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning and relevance and sufficiency of the evidence and identifying when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

By the end of the year, read and comprehend informational texts, including history/social studies, science, and technical texts, at the high end of the grades 4–5 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
Ask and answer such questions as who, what, where, when, why, and how to demonstrate understanding of key details in a text.
Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.

Use combined knowledge of all letter-sound correspondences, syllabication patterns, and morphology (e.g., roots and affixes) to read accurately unfamiliar multisyllabic words in context and out of context.
Ask for clarification and further explanation as needed about the topics and texts under discussion.
Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics.
Correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from the argument presented.
Delineate a speaker’s argument and specific claims, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
Determine the figurative and connotative meanings of phrases as they are used in a text
Compare formal and informal uses of English.
Compare and contrast one author’s presentation of events with that of another (e.g., a memoir written by and a biography on the same person).
Describe how a particular story’s characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories and poetry, in the grades 2–3 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
Spell correctly.
Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.
Explain the function of prepositions in general.
Ask and answer such questions as who, what, where, when, why, and how to demonstrate understanding of key details in a text.
Link opinion and reasons using words, phrases, and clauses (e.g., consequently, specifically).
Draw on information from multiple print or digital sources, demonstrating the ability to locate an answer to a question quickly or to solve a problem efficiently.
Use correlative conjunctions (e.g., either/or, neither/nor).
Determine the literal meaning of words as they are used in a text.
Include multimedia components (e.g., graphics, images, music, sound) and visual displays in presentations to clarify information.
Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).
Create audio recordings of stories or poems; add drawings or other visual displays to stories or recounts of experiences when appropriate to clarify ideas, thoughts, and feelings.
Delineate a speaker’s argument and specific claims, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
Interpret figurative language, including similes and metaphors, in context.
Introduce claim(s), acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically.

Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its part of speech.
Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., bullheaded, willful, firm, persistent, resolute).
Use commas in greetings and closings of letters.
With guidance and support from adults and peers, focus on a topic and strengthen writing as needed by revising and editing.

Come to discussions prepared, having read or researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and reflect on ideas under discussion.
Produce, expand, and rearrange complete simple and compound sentences (e.g., The boy watched the movie; The little boy watched the movie; The action movie was watched by the little boy).
By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of grades 6–8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
Use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., photograph, photosynthesis).
Determine a theme of a poem from details in the text, including how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic.
Correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.
Consult reference materials, including beginning dictionaries, as needed to check and correct spellings.
Recount or describe key ideas or details from a text read aloud or information presented orally or through other media.
Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., cause/effect, part/whole, item/category) to better understand each of the words.
Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to capture the action and convey experiences and events.
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from the information or explanation presented.
Use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., photograph, photosynthesis).
Recount or describe key ideas or details from a text read aloud or information presented orally or through other media.
Analyze how a particular paragraph fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.

Recall relevant information from experiences or gather relevant information from print and digital sources; summarize or paraphrase information in notes and finished work, and provide a list of sources.
Determine a theme of a story from details in the text, including how characters in the story respond to challenges.
Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and present the relationships between information and ideas efficiently as well as to interact and collaborate with others.
Determine the literal meaning of phrases as they are used in a text.
Introduce a topic or text clearly, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure in which ideas are logically grouped to support the writer’s purpose.

By the end of year, read and comprehend informational texts, including history/social studies, science, and technical texts, in the grades 2–3 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
Recognize inappropriate shifts in verb tense.
Explain the function of prepositions in particular sentences.
Explain the function of verbals (gerunds, participles, infinitives) in general and their function in particular sentences.
Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a phrase by using context clues, analyzing meaningful word parts, and consulting general and specialized reference materials, as appropriate.
Maintain consistency in style and tone.
Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.
Explain the function of verbals (gerunds, participles, infinitives) in general and their function in particular sentences.
Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Describe how a narrator’s or speaker’s point of view influences how events are described.
Gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Determine a theme of a drama from details in the text, including how characters in the drama respond to challenges.
Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.
Create audio recordings of stories or poems; add drawings or other visual displays to stories or recounts of experiences when appropriate to clarify ideas, thoughts, and feelings.
Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as necessary.
Ensure that pronouns are in the proper case.

With guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach. (Editing for conventions should demonstrate command of Language standards 1–3 up to and including grade 5.)
Use glossaries and beginning dictionaries, both print and digital, to determine or clarify the meaning of words and phrases.
Use punctuation (comma, ellipsis, dash) to indicate a pause or break.
Capitalize holidays, product names, and geographic names.
Use appropriate and varied transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.
Know spelling-sound correspondences for common vowel teams.
Know and use various text features (e.g., captions, bold print, subheadings, glossaries, indexes, electronic menus, icons) to locate key facts or information in a text efficiently.
Describe how a particular story’s or drama’s plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Describe how reasons support specific points the author makes in a text.
Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Review the key ideas expressed and demonstrate understanding of multiple perspectives through reflection and paraphrasing.
Explain how a series of scenes fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular drama.
Determine the figurative meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text.
Use an apostrophe to form frequently occurring possessives.
Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Determine the figurative meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text.

Introduce a topic clearly, provide a general observation and focus, and group related information logically; include formatting (e.g., headings), illustrations, and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.
Recognize variations from standard English in their own and others' writing and speaking, and identify and use strategies to improve expression in conventional language.
Explain the function of interjections in particular sentences.
Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin roots as clues to the meaning of a word.
Use appropriate and varied transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.
Use reflexive pronouns (e.g., myself, ourselves).
Review the key ideas expressed and demonstrate understanding of multiple perspectives through reflection and paraphrasing.
Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, and description, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.
Decode words with common prefixes and suffixes.
Interpret information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and explain how it contributes to a topic, text, or issue under study.
Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and present the relationships between information and ideas efficiently as well as to interact and collaborate with others.
Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.
Form and use verbs in the indicative, imperative, interrogative, conditional, and subjunctive mood.
Correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.

Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its part of speech.
Determine the literal meaning of words as they are used in a text.
Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.
Compare and contrast stories in the same genre (e.g., mysteries and adventure stories) on their approaches to similar themes and topics.
Explain how specific images (e.g., a diagram showing how a machine works) contribute to and clarify a text.
Include multimedia components (e.g., graphics, sound) and visual displays in presentations when appropriate to enhance the development of main ideas or themes.
Use collective nouns.
Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, and description, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.
Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to capture the action and convey experiences and events.
Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.
